answers.answer: Hi there. There are many possible causes like remaining in the same seated or standing position for a long time, any nerve injury due to neck or low back injury. Pressure on spinal nerves like from herniated disc, lack of blood supply to an area, like cholesterol plaques from atherosclerosis in legs can cause pain, numbness on walking. Other systemic conditions which may cause these symptoms are diabetes, migraines, carpal tunnel syndrome and multiple sclerosis.Other conditions to be ruled out are transient ischemic attacks or raynaud’s phenomenon, Vitamin B12 deficiency etc.Your physician must identify and treat the underlying cause for these symptoms. Certain exercises may help if you have low back and carpal tunnel syndrome. Diabetes should be managed with strict dietary control and exercise. Vitamin supplements to be given if low levels are detected. Any medications found to be the culprits need to be switched and any excess vitamin supplements to be avoided.Take care.

question: I have recently started experiencing episodes of numbness on my right side starting at my cheek and extending down my arms and hands as well as my right leg and foot... it happens when I either lean over and stand up or am sitting down and stand up.  The symptoms don't last long; I usually walk it off. I have taken  my blood pressure during an attack and my pressure is normal as well as my heart rate.   I do take a channel blocker blood   pressure medication. I do have a history of panic attacks but have never experienced these symptoms. I work a great deal; actually 7 days a week because I have my own business but need insurance.
title: numbness and tingling on the right side of my body
